Literature Review: The INFOGEST in vitro digestion model, developed by an international consortium, has emerged as a pivotal tool in simulating the human gastrointestinal (GI) tract's physicochemical processes during food digestion. This model meticulously replicates the conditions of the mouth, stomach, and small intestine, offering a standardized approach to study the digestion of macronutrients, the bioaccessibility of bioactive compounds, and the structural changes in foods under GI conditions. The INFOGEST method's application spans a wide array of food categories, including dairy, egg, meat, seafood, fruit, vegetable, cereal, and emulsified products, as well as next-generation plant-based foods, providing insights into their digestibility and nutritional impact. The digestion of macronutrients—lipids, proteins, and starch—is a critical aspect of the INFOGEST model. Studies have demonstrated its efficacy in assessing the hydrolysis of lipids into free fatty acids and monoacylglycerols, the breakdown of proteins into peptides and amino acids, and the conversion of starch into simpler sugars, mirroring the physiological processes in the human GI tract (Minekus et al., 2014). The model's ability to measure the bioaccessibility of bioactive agents, such as vitamins, minerals, and nutraceuticals, is particularly noteworthy. By simulating the GI environment, researchers can evaluate the release and absorption potential of these compounds, which is crucial for understanding their bioavailability and health benefits (Bohn et al., 2018). Furthermore, the INFOGEST model has been instrumental in studying the structural and physical changes in foods during digestion. Parameters such as particle size, charge, and location are meticulously analyzed to understand how food matrices evolve in the GI tract, affecting nutrient release and absorption (Grundy et al., 2016). The application of the INFOGEST method to various food categories has provided valuable insights into their gastrointestinal fate. For instance, studies on dairy products have elucidated the digestion kinetics of casein and whey proteins, while research on meat and seafood has focused on protein digestibility and the release of essential amino acids (Dupont et al., 2018). The model has also been applied to fruits and vegetables to assess the bioaccessibility of phytochemicals and dietary fibers, and to cereal products to study starch digestibility and glycemic index (Brodkorb et al., 2019). In the realm of next-generation plant-based foods, the INFOGEST model has been pivotal in evaluating the digestibility of meat, seafood, dairy, and egg analogs. These studies are crucial for understanding the nutritional equivalence of plant-based alternatives to their animal-derived counterparts and for guiding product development to enhance their health benefits (McClements et al., 2020). Despite its widespread application, the INFOGEST model has limitations, including the simplification of the GI tract's complexity and the variability in experimental conditions across studies. However, its benefits, such as the standardization of in vitro digestion protocols and the ability to screen a wide range of food products, outweigh these limitations, making it an invaluable tool in food science and nutrition research (Egger et al., 2017). In conclusion, the INFOGEST in vitro digestion model has significantly advanced our understanding of food digestion, nutrient bioaccessibility, and the structural changes in foods under GI conditions. Its application across diverse food categories and next-generation plant-based foods underscores its versatility and importance in developing healthier and more sustainable food products.
